instruction: Q1) A database is decided for a large construction enterprise to support its resources management. Such an enterprise has a set of Departments and Projects. Each department has a set of Equipment. Equipment's are assigned to projects for a specific period of time. • No equipment is assigned to more than one project at a time. • An equipment could be idle for a given period of time. • The database is to contain the following information: o Department data together, with data concerning the equipment of each department. Project's data together with necessary data of all equipment assigned to each project (start and finish dates of assigning an equipment to a project). For each department: department number (unique), name (unique), and budget. For each equipment: equipment number (unique), name, store location. For each project: project number (unique), name, location, project start date and project
output:
A1: Entity Types and Attributes
1. DEPARTMENT
   a. Attributes: Dept_Number (PK), Name (Unique), Budget
2. EQUIPMENT
   a. Attributes: Equipment_Number (PK), Name, Location
3. PROJECT
   a. Attributes: Project_Number (PK), Name , LOCATION

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Has
   a. Between: DEPARTMENT and EQUIPMENT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One DEPARTMENT has many EQUIPMENT.
    ii. Each EQUIPMENT belongs to one DEPARTMENT.
    c. DEPARTMENT (1:M) EQUIPMENT
2. Assigns
   a. Between: EQUIPMENT and PROJECT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One EQUIPMENT is assigned to at most one PROJECT at a time
    ii. One PROJECT uses many EQUIPMENT.
    c. Relationship Attributes: Start_Date, Finish_Date
    d. EQUIPMENT (M:1) PROJECT

instruction: Q2) A database is decided for a large construction enterprise to support its resources management. Such an enterprise has a set of Departments and Projects. Each department has a set of Equipment. Equipment's are assigned to projects for a specific period of time. • equipment is assigned to more than one project at a time. • the project may use the same equipment more than one time. • An equipment could be idle for a given period of time. • The database is to contain the following information: o Department data together, with data concerning the equipment of each department. Project's data together with necessary data of all equipment assigned to each project (start and finish dates of assigning an equipment to a project). For each department: department number (unique), name (unique), and budget. For each equipment: equipment number (unique), name, store location. For each project: project number (unique), name, location, project start date and project
output:
A2: Entity Types and Attributes
1. DEPARTMENT
   a. Attributes: Dept_Number (PK), Name (Unique), Budget
2. EQUIPMENT
   a. Attributes: Equipment_Number (PK), Name
3. PROJECT
   a. Attributes: Project_Number (PK), Name, NAME , LOCATION
4. TRANSACTION
   a. Attributes: TNO (PK) , START_DATE , END_DATE

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Has
   a. Between: DEPARTMENT and EQUIPMENT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One DEPARTMENT has many EQUIPMENT.
    ii. Each EQUIPMENT belongs to one DEPARTMENT.
    c. DEPARTMENT (1:M) EQUIPMENT
2. Assigns
   a. Between: EQUIPMENT and TRANSACTION
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One EQUIPMENT can be assigned to many TRANSACTIONS over time.
    ii. ONE TRANSACTION BELONG TO ONE EQUIPMENT.
    c. EQUIPMENT (1:M) TRANSACTION
3. Assigns
   a. Between: PROJECT and TRANSACTION
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One PROJECT can be assigned to many TRANSACTIONS over time.
    ii. ONE TRANSACTION BELONG TO ONE PROJECT.
    c. PROJECT (1:M) TRANSACTION

instruction: Question 3: A database is to contain information concerning sales representatives, sales areas, and products. Each representative is responsible for sales in only one area. Each area may have one or more responsible representatives. Each representative is responsible for sales of one or more products, and each product has one or more responsible representatives. A sales commission is assigned to each representative. The commission rate is determined according to the sales area, in other words, for each area there is a certain fixed commission rate for all responsible representatives of that area. The database is to contain the following information: • For each representative: representative number (unique), representative name (unique), and sales commission. • For each sales area: area number (unique), and location. • For each product: product number (unique), product name and quantity sold by each representative in each area.
output:
A3: Entity Types and Attributes
1. REPRESENTATIVE
   a. Attributes: Rep_Number (PK), Name (Unique), Sales_Commission
2. AREA
   a. Attributes: Area_Number (PK), Location, Commission_Rate
3. PRODUCT
   a. Attributes: Product_Number (PK), Name

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Responsible_For
   a. Between: AREA and REPRESENTATIVE
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One REPRESENTATIVE is responsible for exactly one AREA.
    ii. One AREA has one or more REPRESENTATIVES.
   c. AREA (1:M) REPRESENTATIVE
2. Sells (Representative-Product)
   a. Between: REPRESENTATIVE and PRODUCT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One REPRESENTATIVE sells one or more PRODUCTS.
    ii. One PRODUCT is sold by one or more REPRESENTATIVES.
   c. Modeled as an associative entity: SALES_RECORD
    i. Attributes: Quantity_Sold
   d. REPRESENTATIVE (M:N) PRODUCT via SALES_RECORD

instruction: Question 4: A database is to contain information concerning sales representatives, sales areas, and products. Each representative is responsible for sales in more than one area. Each area may have one or more responsible representatives. Each representative is responsible for sales of one or more products, and each product has one or more responsible representatives. A sales commission is assigned to each representative. The commission rate is determined according to the sales area, in other words, for each area there is a certain fixed commission rate for all responsible representatives of that area. The database is to contain the following information: • For each representative: representative number (unique), representative name (unique), and sales commission. • For each sales area: area number (unique), and location. • For each product: product number (unique), product name and quantity sold by each representative in each area .
output:
A4: Entity Types and Attributes
1. REPRESENTATIVE
   a. Attributes: Rep_Number (PK), Name (Unique)
2. AREA
   a. Attributes: Area_Number (PK), Location, Commission_Rate
3. PRODUCT
   a. Attributes: Product_Number (PK), Name

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. HAS
   a. Between: AREA and REPRESENTIVE
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One AREA HAS more than one REPRESENTIVE
    ii. One REPRESENTIVE has more than one AREA.
    c. AREA (M:N) REPRESENTIVE
2. HAS
   a. Between: REPRESENTATIVE, PRODUCT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One REPRESENTITIVE HAS more than one PRODUCT.
    ii. One PRODUCT has MORE THAN one REPRESENTITIVE.
    c. REPRESENTITIVE (M:N) PRODUCT

instruction: Question 5: A database is to contain information concerning sales representatives, sales areas, and products. Each representative is responsible for sales in more than one area. Each area may have one or more responsible representatives. Each representative is responsible for sales of one or more products, and each product has one or more responsible representatives. A sales commission is assigned to each representative. The commission rate is determined according to the sales area, in other words, for each area there is a certain fixed commission rate for all responsible representatives of that area. The database is to contain the following information: • For each representative: representative number (unique), representative name (unique), and sales commission. • For each sales area: area number (unique), and location. • For each product: product number (unique), product name and quantity sold by each representative in each area, assume that the quantity of the same product not sold in one time.
output:
A99: Entity Types and Attributes
1. REPRESENTATIVE
   b. Attributes: Rep_Number (PK), Name (Unique)
2. AREA
   c. Attributes: Area_Number (PK), Location, Commission_Rate
3. PRODUCT
   d. Attributes: Product_Number (PK), Name
4. TRANSACTION
   e. Attributes: TNO (PK) , QUANTITY , SUB_QUQNITTY (DERIVED)

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. HAS
   e. Between: AREA and REPRESENTIVE
   f. Cardinality:
    i. One AREA HAS more than one REPRESENTIVE
    ii. One REPRESENTIVE has more than one AREA.
   g. AREA (M:N) REPRESENTIVE
2. HAS
   h. Between: REPRESENTATIVE, PRODUCT
   i. Cardinality:
    i. One REPRESENTITIVE HAS more than one PRODUCT.
    ii. One PRODUCT has MORE THAN one REPRESENTITIVE.
   j. REPRESENTITIVE (M:N) PRODUCT
3. HAS
   k. Between: REPRESENTATIVE, TRANSACTION
   l. Cardinality:
    i. One REPRESENTITIVE HAS more than one TRANSACTION.
    ii. One TRANSACTION has one REPRESENTITIVE.
   m. REPRESENTITIVE (1:M) TRANSACTION
4. HAS
   n. Between: AREA, TRANSACTION
   o. Cardinality:
    i. One AREA HAS more than one TRANSACTION.
    ii. One TRANSACTION has one REPRESENTITIVE.
   p. AREA(1:M) TRANSACTION
5. HAS
   q. Between: TRANSACTION, PRODUCT
   r. Cardinality:
    i. One PRODUCT HAS more than one TRANSACTION.
    ii. One TRANSACTION has one PRODUCT.
   s. PRODUCT(M:1) TRANSACTION

instruction: Question 6: A database is decided for scheduling the coming football tournament of World Cup in France. The participating teams are divided into groups each of 8 teams. The designed database must contain data about: • Teams described by country, coach, and the score of these team in each match. • Groups described by group number, teams in that groups and the group supervisor name. • Matches described by match id (unique), the teams, referee name, referee number, referee id, referee rank, court number, court city and date. • Players described by teams, player number, player name, player position in the team, number of goals for each player in each match.(BOOK QUESTION)
output:
A5: Entity Types and Attributes
1. TEAM
   a. Attributes: Country (PK), Coach
2. GROUP
   a. Attributes: Group_Number (PK), Supervisor_Name
3. MATCH
   a. Attributes: Match_ID (PK), Referee_Name, Referee_Number, Referee_ID, Referee_Rank, Court_Number, Court_City, Date, HOME SCORE, AWAY SCORE
4. PLAYER
   a. Attributes: Player_Number (PK), Name, Position

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Belongs_To
   a. Between: GROUP and TEAM
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One GROUP contains 8 TEAMS.
    ii. Each TEAM belongs to one GROUP.
    c. GROUP (1:M) TEAM
2. SCORE AWAY
   a. Between: TEAM and MATCH
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One MATCH is between two TEAMS.
    ii. One TEAM plays in many MATCHES.
    c. TEAM (1:N) MATCH
3. SCORE HOME
   a. Between: TEAM and MATCH
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One MATCH is between two TEAMS.
    ii. One TEAM plays in many MATCHES.
    c. TEAM (1:N) MATCH
4. Member_Of
   a. Between: TEAM and PLAYER
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One TEAM has many PLAYERS.
    ii. Each PLAYER belongs to one TEAM.
   c. TEAM (1:M) PLAYER
5. Scores_In (OPTIONAL)
   a. Between: PLAYER and MATCH
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One PLAYER scores in many MATCHES.
    ii. One MATCH has goals from many PLAYERS.
   c. Modeled as an associative entity: GOAL_RECORD
    i. Attributes: Number_Of_Goals
   d. PLAYER (M:N) MATCH via GOAL_RECORD

instruction: Question 7: A database is decided for scheduling the coming football tournament of World Cup in France. The participating teams are divided into groups each of 8 teams. The designed database must contain data about: • Teams described by country, coach, and the score of these team in each match. • Groups described by group number, teams in that groups and the group supervisor name. • Matches described by match id (unique), the teams, referee name, referee number, referee id, referee rank, court number, court city and date. • Players described by teams, player number, player name, player position in the team, number of goals for each player in each match.(ADDING REFEREE ENTITY)
output:
A5: Entity Types and Attributes
1. TEAM
   b. Attributes: Country (PK), Coach
2. GROUP
   c. Attributes: Group_Number (PK), Supervisor_Name
3. MATCH
   d. Attributes: Match_ID (PK), Court_Number, Court_City, Date , HOME SCORE , AWAY SCORE
4. PLAYER
   e. Attributes: Player_Number (PK), Name, Position
5. referee
   f. Attributes: REFEREE_NUM , REFEREE_ID (PK) , REFEREE_RANK , NAME

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Belongs_To
   d. Between: GROUP and TEAM
   e. Cardinality:
    i. One GROUP contains 8 TEAMS.
    ii. Each TEAM belongs to one GROUP.
   f. GROUP (1:M) TEAM
2. SCORE AWAY
   g. Between: TEAM and MATCH
   h. Cardinality:
    i. One MATCH is between two TEAMS.
    ii. One TEAM plays in many MATCHES.
   i. TEAM (1:N) MATCH
3. SCORE HOME
   j. Between: TEAM and MATCH
   k. Cardinality:
    i. One MATCH is between two TEAMS.
    ii. One TEAM plays in many MATCHES.
   l. TEAM (1:N) MATCH
4. Member_Of
   e. Between: TEAM and PLAYER
   f. Cardinality:
    i. One TEAM has many PLAYERS.
    ii. Each PLAYER belongs to one TEAM.
   g. TEAM (1:M) PLAYER
5. Scores_In (OPTIONAL)
   h. Between: PLAYER and MATCH
   i. Cardinality:
    i. One PLAYER scores in many MATCHES.
    ii. One MATCH has goals from many PLAYERS.
   j. Modeled as an associative entity: GOAL_RECORD
    i. Attributes: Number_Of_Goals
   k. PLAYER (M:N) MATCH via GOAL_RECORD
6. HAS
   l. Between: MATCH and REFEREE
   m. Cardinality:
    i. One MATCH has ONE REFEREE.
    ii. Each REFEREE HAS MORE THAN ONE MATCH.
   n. MATCH(M:1) REFEREE

instruction: Question 8: Consider the following set of requirements for the EGYPTAIR database which contains information about the airline flight system of that national company: Each FLIGHT is identified by a flight number, flight code and date. Each flight consists of one or more flight legs. A flight leg is a nonstop portion of a flight. • Each FLIGHT LEG has a number (1, 2, 3, etc.), departure airport, scheduled departure time (day-hour-min), arrival airport, scheduled arrival time (dayhour-min), and airplane. The leg number is unique for flight legs of the same flight. • Each AIRPORT has code (unique), name, and city • Each AIRPLANE TYPE has type name (unique), company, and maximum number of seats. Each airplane type can land only on certain airports. There is a set of airplanes for each airplane type. • Each AIRPLANE has ID number (unique for airplanes of the same type), and technical status (in service, out of service, in maintenance, ... etc.).
output:
A6: Entity Types and Attributes
1. FLIGHT
   a. Attributes: Flight_CODE (PK),FLIGHT_NUMBER, Date
2. FLIGHT_LEG
   a. Attributes: Leg_Number (PK, composite with Flight_Number), Departure_Airport_Code, Scheduled_Departure_Time, Arrival_Airport_Code, Scheduled_Arrival_Time
3. AIRPORT
   a. Attributes: Airport_Code (PK), Name, City
4. AIRPLANE_TYPE
   a. Attributes: Type_Name (PK), Company, Max_Seats
5. AIRPLANE
   a. Attributes: Airplane_ID (PK, composite with Type_Name), Technical_Status

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Consists_Of
   a. Between: FLIGHT and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One FLIGHT consists of one or more FLIGHT_LEGs.
    ii. Each FLIGHT_LEG is part of one FLIGHT.
    c. FLIGHT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG
2. Departs_From / Arrives_At
   a. Between: FLIGHT_LEG and AIRPORT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG departs from one AIRPORT and arrives at one AIRPORT.
    ii. One AIRPORT is used for many departures and arrivals.
    c. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG (for departure)
    d. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG (for arrival)
3. Can_Land_On
   a. Between: AIRPLANE_TYPE and AIRPORT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One AIRPLANE_TYPE can land on many AIRPORTS.
    ii. One AIRPORT can support many AIRPLANE_TYPEs.
    c. AIRPLANE_TYPE (M:N) AIRPORT
4. Is_Of_Type
   a. Between: AIRPLANE_TYPE and AIRPLANE
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One AIRPLANE_TYPE has a set of AIRPLANEs.
    ii. Each AIRPLANE is of one AIRPLANE_TYPE.
    c. AIRPLANE_TYPE (1:M) AIRPLANE
5. Assigned_To
   a. Between: AIRPLANE and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG is assigned one AIRPLANE.
    ii. One AIRPLANE is assigned to many FLIGHT_LEGs over time.
    c. AIRPLANE (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG
6. ARRIVAL TIME
   a. Between: AIRPORT and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG is assigned one AIRPORT.
    ii. One AIRPORT is assigned to many FLIGHT_LEGs over time.
    c. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG
7. DEPARTURE TIME
   a. Between: AIRPORT and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG is assigned one AIRPORT.
    ii. One AIRPORT is assigned to many FLIGHT_LEGs over time.
    c. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG

instruction: Question 9: Consider the following set of requirements for the EGYPTAIR database which contains information about the airline flight system of that national company: Each FLIGHT is identified by a flight number, has weekdays. Each flight consists of one or more flight legs. A flight leg is a nonstop portion of a flight. • Each FLIGHT LEG has a number (1, 2, 3, etc.), departure airport, scheduled departure time (day-hour-min), arrival airport, scheduled arrival time (dayhour-min), and airplane. The leg number is unique for flight legs of the same flight. • Each AIRPORT has code (unique), name, and city • Each AIRPLANE TYPE has type name (unique), company, and maximum number of seats. Each airplane type can land only on certain airports. There is a set of airplanes for each airplane type. • Each AIRPLANE has ID number (unique for airplanes of the same type), and technical status (in service, out of service, in maintenance, ... etc.).
output:
AG: Entity Types and Attributes
1. FLIGHT
   a. Attributes: Flight_Number(PK),Weekdays
2. FLIGHT_LEG
   a. Attributes: Leg_Number (PK, composite with Flight_Number), Departure_Airport_Code, Scheduled_Departure_Time, Arrival_Airport_Code, Scheduled_Arrival_Time
3. AIRPORT
   a. Attributes: Airport_Code (PK), Name, City
4. AIRPLANE_TYPE
   a. Attributes: Type_Name (PK), Company, Max_Seats
5. AIRPLANE
   a. Attributes: Airplane_ID (PK, composite with Type_Name), Technical_Status

Relationships and Cardinalities
8. Consists_Of
   a. Between: FLIGHT and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One FLIGHT consists of one or more FLIGHT_LEGs.
    ii. Each FLIGHT_LEG is part of one FLIGHT.
    c. FLIGHT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG
9. Departs_From / Arrives_At
   a. Between: FLIGHT_LEG and AIRPORT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG departs from one AIRPORT and arrives at one AIRPORT.
    ii. One AIRPORT is used for many departures and arrivals.
    c. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG (for departure)
    d. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG (for arrival)
10. Can_Land_On
   a. Between: AIRPLANE_TYPE and AIRPORT
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One AIRPLANE_TYPE can land on many AIRPORTS.
    ii. One AIRPORT can support many AIRPLANE_TYPEs.
    c. AIRPLANE_TYPE (M:N) AIRPORT
11. Is_Of_Type
   a. Between: AIRPLANE_TYPE and AIRPLANE
   b. Cardinality:
    i. One AIRPLANE_TYPE has a set of AIRPLANEs.
    ii. Each AIRPLANE is of one AIRPLANE_TYPE.
    c. AIRPLANE_TYPE (1:M) AIRPLANE
12. Assigned_To
   a. Between: AIRPLANE and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG is assigned one AIRPLANE.
    ii. One AIRPLANE is assigned to many FLIGHT_LEGs over time.
    c. AIRPLANE (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG
13. ARRIVAL TIME
   a. Between: AIRPORT and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG is assigned one AIRPORT.
    ii. One AIRPORT is assigned to many FLIGHT_LEGs over time.
    c. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG
14. DEPARTURE TIME
   a. Between: AIRPORT and FLIGHT_LEG
   b. Cardinality:
    i. Each FLIGHT_LEG is assigned one AIRPORT.
    ii. One AIRPORT is assigned to many FLIGHT_LEGs over time.
    c. AIRPORT (1:M) FLIGHT_LEG

instruction:
Question 10: A database is to contain information about the internal education system of a large industrial company. The company in question maintains an education department whose function is to run several training courses for the employees of the company; each course is offered at a number of different locations within the organization, and the database contains details both of offerings already given and of offerings scheduled to be given in future. The database contains the following information:- For each course: course number (unique), course title, details of all immediate prerequisite course, and details of all offerings For each offering, of a given course; offering number, date, location, details of the teacher, and details of all students For each teacher of a given offering; employee number (unique), and name For each student of a given offering; employee number (unique), name, and grad
The following constraints apply
- Teacher can be teach only one offer
- Prerequisite more than course
- For each course, all offerings of that course are taught by only one teacher
- A teacher may teach more than one course type
output:
A10: Entity Types and Attributes
1. COURSE
   o Attributes: Course_Number (PK), composite with Employee_teacher_Number(PK), course_Title.
2. OFFERING
   o Attributes: Offering_Number (PK), composite with Course_Number(PK), Offering_Date, Location,Employee_teacher_Number.
   o Note: OFFERING is a week entity.
3. TEACHER
   o Attributes: Employee_Number(PK), Name
4. STUDENT
   o Attributes: Employee_Number(PK), Name
5. ENROLLMENT
   o Attributes: Offering_Number(PK), composite with Employee_Student_Number(PK), Grade

Relationships and Cardinalities
1. Has_Offering
   o Between: COURSE and OFFERING
   o Cardinality:
    - One COURSE has many OFFERINGS.
    - Each OFFERING is for one COURSE.
   o COURSE (1:M) OFFERING
2. Teaches
   o Between: TEACHER and OFFERING
   o Cardinality:
    - For each COURSE, all its OFFERINGS are taught by one TEACHER.
    - One TEACHER can teach many OFFERINGS (of the same or different courses).
   o TEACHER (1:M) OFFERING
3. Enroll
   o Between: STUDENT and OFFERING
   o Cardinality:
    - One STUDENT can attend many OFFERINGS.
    - One OFFERING has many STUDENTS.
   o STUDENT (M:N) OFFERING
4. Has_Prerequisite
   o Between: COURSE and COURSE
   o Cardinality:
    - MANY COURSE CAN BE A PREQUISITE
    - One PREQUISITE can BE FOR MANY COURSES.
   o COURSE (M:M) COURSE
5. Assigned
   o Between: COURSE and TEACHER
   o Cardinality:
    - A Teacher may teach more than one course type
    - Many Courses are Assigned by only one teacher
   o TEACHER (1:M)COURSE
